docs.abstract: Republican senators want to create $425 billion in funding to back Fed emergency lending.
docs.snippet: Republican senators want to create $425 billion in funding to back Fed emergency lending.
docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans have proposed giving the Federal Reserve access to $425 billion in funding that it could use to extend emergency support to flailing businesses or struggling localities — an approach that would keep central bankers at the center of the coronavirus economic response in ways that could prove politically fraught.

headline.main: Fed Could Bolster Groups of Businesses and Localities With Funds in G.O.P. Bill
headline.print_headline: Republicans Push Dispersal Of $425 Billion Through Fed

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)

byline.original: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport

docs.abstract: With coronavirus fears engulfing New York City and markets tanking, the finance industry is busier than ever — and learning to work from home.
docs.snippet: With coronavirus fears engulfing New York City and markets tanking, the finance industry is busier than ever — and learning to work from home.
docs.lead_paragraph: Investors, corporations and trading clients are turning to Wall Street amid one of the most tumultuous periods in market history to borrow money, buy or sell assets, and limit losses on existing holdings. But Wall Street itself is grappling with a challenge it had never faced: how to protect employees from a worsening public-health threat while managing clients who need their services around the clock.

headline.main: Amid Virus and Market Tumult, Wall Street Lives a New Reality
headline.print_headline: Wall Street Adjusts to a New Reality

docs.abstract: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
docs.snippet: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you couldn’t join us on Friday for our special conference call about the business and policy implications of the coronavirus pandemic, the recording is here. The response was enormous — more than 4,000 of you signed up to participate — so we couldn’t get to all of the questions. What should we cover in future calls? Let us know. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline.main: What Will Fill a $4 Trillion Hole in the Economy?

docs.abstract: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
docs.snippet: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
docs.lead_paragraph: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.

headline.main: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring

byline.original: By David Gelles and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: The coronavirus is likely to hasten the end of advertising-driven media, our columnist writes. And government should not rescue it.
docs.snippet: The coronavirus is likely to hasten the end of advertising-driven media, our columnist writes. And government should not rescue it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Green was musing the other day about buying 261 newspapers.

headline.main: Bail Out Journalists. Let Newspaper Chains Die.
headline.print_headline: Bailing Out Publishers Is Pure Folly

docs.abstract: Estate planning lawyers we talked to this week said they had been getting more calls since the outbreak worsened.
docs.snippet: Estate planning lawyers we talked to this week said they had been getting more calls since the outbreak worsened.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Joel Solomon sold his financial services firm in mid-January, he had been planning to call his estate lawyer to update his will and trusts. But with coronavirus cases spiking, Mr. Solomon and his wife, Nancy, decided to act immediately.

headline.main: What to Know About Making a Will in the Age of Coronavirus
headline.print_headline: Making a Will (or Updating One) Just Became More Complex

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Living Wills and Health Care Proxies

docs.abstract: With grants and marketing spending, the social media giant hopes to support outlets doing essential local reporting but struggling with a drop in advertising.
docs.snippet: With grants and marketing spending, the social media giant hopes to support outlets doing essential local reporting but struggling with a drop in advertising.
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook announced on Monday that it would dole out $25 million in grants to local news outlets and spend $75 million in a marketing drive aimed at news organizations internationally in response to the coronavirus-prompted economic downturn, which has caused advertising to plummet and has threatened media industry revenues.

headline.main: Facebook Aims $100 Million at Media Hit by the Coronavirus
headline.print_headline: Facebook Will Give $100 Million to Media Reeling From Virus

docs.abstract: The two companies are the latest targets of labor action by groups fearing virus exposure on the job.
docs.snippet: The two companies are the latest targets of labor action by groups fearing virus exposure on the job.
docs.lead_paragraph: Signaling both growing anxiety and growing solidarity brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, workers in a variety of occupations across the country are protesting what they see as inadequate safety measures and insufficient pay for the risks they are confronting.

headline.main: Strikes at Instacart and Amazon Over Coronavirus Health Concerns

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: United Food and Commercial Workers Union

byline.original: By Noam Scheiber and Kate Conger

docs.abstract: The use of gasoline and other fuels is dropping as Saudi Arabia and Russia increase production, sending oil prices to their lowest level in a generation.
docs.snippet: The use of gasoline and other fuels is dropping as Saudi Arabia and Russia increase production, sending oil prices to their lowest level in a generation.
docs.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The once mighty oil industry is shrinking quickly around the world, hunkering down in survival mode.

headline.main: Oil Companies on Tumbling Prices: ‘Disastrous, Devastating’
headline.print_headline: With the Price of Oil Plummeting, Storage Tanks Are Near Capacity

docs.abstract: As the coronavirus has prolonged a deep slump in Japan, one ray of hope has come from its avoidance of a crippling lockdown. But it’s unclear whether that can last.
docs.snippet: As the coronavirus has prolonged a deep slump in Japan, one ray of hope has come from its avoidance of a crippling lockdown. But it’s unclear whether that can last.
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Even before the new coronavirus, Japan’s economy was in trouble. Exports were plummeting on slowing demand from China, and a tax increase at home was keeping shoppers out of stores. The numbers were stark: Economic output contracted 7.1 percent in the last quarter of 2019.

headline.main: Can Japan’s Economy Get Any Worse? It May Soon Find Out
headline.print_headline: Olympics Delay Can Only Worsen Japan’s Slump

byline.original: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
